content:
Workforce Engagement uses average handle times to estimate staffing needs in a capacity plan. Average handle times indicate the length of a typical customer interaction. 

Available in: Enterprise, Performance, and Unlimited Editions.

In an Omni-Channel queue-based workflow, Workforce Engagement calculates average handle times from your Omni data. If your channel data includes handle times, specify a numeric field that contains that data when you create the workload history.

If your workload history lacks handle time data, define per-channel defaults when you create a capacity plan. Handle times can vary widely and make accurate predictions difficult for extended interactions like cases.

When Workforce Engagement estimates staffing, it's recommended to create plans with long durations. Select a date range that extends beyond the average handle time and use a date filter on the plan results to focus on a shorter time frame.

A call center handles both cases and voice calls. For each channel, Workforce Engagement considers how long it takes to complete an interaction and how many interactions an agent can handle concurrently.

For the Case channel, it takes an agent 4 weeks (200 hours) to create and close a case. For the voice channel, an agent takes one call at a time and the average call length is 30 minutes.

To create a capacity plan, set the plan duration for at least four weeks and specify characteristics for each channel in the job profile. The planner specifies Voice as priority 1 and Case as priority 2. They assign 50 work units for the Voice channel and 1 work unit for the Case channel.

Average handle times are set for the Voice channel to 30 minutes and for the Case channel to 200 hours. Service level agreements (SLAs) are also set, such as completing 85% of calls within 2 hours and answering 80% of cases within 250 hours.

The planner names the capacity plan and saves the configuration.
title: Set Average Handle Times in Service Cloud
